we have a fresh reminder this morning

we've got to keep fighting fight for

[Music]
I want to welcome you to this morning's
panel I think you're in for a really
fascinating discussion this is about
ending the epidemic science advances on
AIDS 2013 marks 30 years since
researchers first identified the virus
that causes AIDS and the statistics are
really daunting since the early 1980s
more than 60 million people worldwide
have been infected with HIV some 25
million have died more than 1 million
Americans are currently living with HIV
and each year 50,000 people in the u.s.
are infected 20% of them do not even
know that they have the virus New York
City has the highest number of new HIV
cases in the nation this morning we're
going to be exploring what science is
doing some of the breakthroughs that you
just heard about some of the challenges
that still arise and we're gonna be
putting a face on people who are living
with AIDS what they're experiencing the
group of people that we have assembled
here today are some of the world's
leading experts on HIV our first
panelist was awarded the Nobel Prize in
Physiology or medicine for his discovery
of reverse transcriptase he's the former
president of the Rockefeller University
and the California Institute of
Technology now he's the founder of Cal
immune biotech company he's working to
develop innovative gene therapies for
HIV please welcome David Baltimore
next he was one of the original members
of act up and he's featured in a recent
documentary film about it entitled how
to survive a plague he founded the
treatment action group and AIDS meds
calm and he's spoken out about HIV and
AIDS on CNN Nightline 60 minutes and the
pages of the New York Times The Wall
Street Journal and rolling stone among
others please welcome Peter Staley
she's a pathologist and immunologist who
consulted on some of the first cases of
what came to be known as AIDS as
professor at NYU's School of Medicine
and director of AIDS research at the New
York Veterans Affairs Medical Center's
she's been trying to solve its medical
mysteries ever since please welcome
Susan Zola Posner and he's a professor
of medicine at the University of
California San Francisco and a senior
investigator at the Gladstone Institute
of our ology and immunology he's run
clinical trials on AIDS drugs all over
the world and was named one of Time
Magazine's 100 most influential people
of 2012 please welcome our final
panelist Bob grant so thank you thank
you all for being here and and all of
you for coming out there been promising
breakthroughs in the past year and also
some some setbacks that we're gonna
examine but but I want to start now with
with the beginning and explore some of
your personal experiences during during
those early years when you became
involved in the fight against HIV and
AIDS so Susan to start with start with
you you've been on the frontlines of
this since the beginning I want you to
take us back to 1981 82 and and share
some of your experience about how you
got involved in what that was like so
there was a telephone call that I got in
the summer of 1981 from a dermatologist
at NYU dr. Alvin Friedman keen who said
that he had seen four young men with an
unusual presentation of skin cancer
called Kaposi sarcoma and since I was
running my research lab studying cancer
and also clinical immunology lab at NYU
he asked me if I could look at the
immune function of these four patients
and they all look
and very unusual in terms of the number
of what we call cd4 lymphocytes a type
of white blood cell in in blood some of
these patients had none of these cells
which is this extremely unusual by the
end of 1981 we had about twenty of these
patients and when you do anything in the
lab you have to run controls along with
your experiments and so we were using
blood from people in the lab as our
normal controls and we said well this
isn't right but we need because we'd
realized that all these patients at this
point would young gay man we needed
young gay men healthy as our controls
and so I contacted a physician here in
the city who had primarily gay practice
and we got specimens from 40 of his
healthy patients and we did the same
Studies on them as we did on our
campus's patients and I will never
forget because for me it was the most
dramatic day of the last 32 years in
terms of this epidemic we looked at the
results in the we realized that a third
of these healthy men who had no symptoms
whatsoever looked exactly like the 20
men with Kaposi sarcoma and we knew at
that point that whatever was going on
and we didn't know what was going on but
whatever was going on a third of the gay
population in the city were subjected to
it - it's really an incredibly chilling
moment and my professional life you know
it began in a sense and and has never
stopped since that moment David how did
you get involved in hiv/aids well
actually it goes back to 1970 because I
was then trying to understand how a
cancer inducing virus grows and
discovered that there was a
characteristic enzyme in the virus
particles which copied RNA into DNA
which first of all was was revolutionary
in itself but what it did was to provide
a marker for this class of viruses now
fast-forward to 83 84 and it was using
that as a diagnostic that enabled gallo
and montagnier and others to find the
HIV virus and to provide the explanation
for what Susan described which was the
ability of this virus to wipe out the
cd4 lymphocytes and to put patients in a
totally immunodeficient situation so I
sort of accidentally found myself
involved and then in 86 I was asked to
head the panel for the National Academy
of Sciences to look at our research
response to this I led a group that
asked for a billion dollars a year and
researched a billion dollars a year in
clinical investigations to move this
problem forward and that was many-fold
what was being spent at the time and we
actually found felt a bit that we were
being audacious and asking for it but in
fact within a couple of years we were
spending a billion dollars a year and I
think we can say that today we
understand this virus better than any
other virus on earth because we've put
these really impressive resources behind
understanding it has it actually stopped
the epidemic again we will we will get
to that Bob you were you were involved
from the beginning
well actually compared to the others
panel I would say come in late 1983 I
was a second-year medical student at San
Francisco and Berkeley and I knew I was
interested in social medicine how
medicine could interact with society and
I was looking for a job and and I wanted
to study heart disease among city bus
drivers but there was no work there
somebody said you know study this thing
called gay bowel disease you know
there's there's money coming in to
understand the epidemic and so you know
and there was there was plenty to do and
it was exciting work imagine me at 23
year olds trying to discover a career or
trying to make a career and this was
something where you know they needed all
hands on deck i mean i i'd taken
computer programming classes and so they
said we need you
you needed epidemiologists you needed
biologists and and there was nothing
more exciting than this I mean
retroviruses had just been discovered
and and and and this was one and and I
got paid half time to talk about sex I
mean it doesn't really get better than
that as a 23 year old so it's it really
set the course of my career there have
been times when I've been discouraged
that the next phase of my career I was
told not to focus on AIDS because by the
time I was fully trained the epidemic
would be over and that was 1987 and and
to this day I don't know whether the the
person giving me this advice was
optimistic about the end of AIDS or
pessimistic about how long it was gonna
take for me to be fully trained
but but that is a commitment that I want
to retire after this epidemic is over
and your work is taking you around the
world and we'll get to some of that in a
little bit but Peter I want to bring you
in your your involvement in this came
from a totally different approach you're
the the one non-scientists here here on
the panel tell us your story how you
came to be involved well the virus very
directly brought me into it I arrived in
New York fresh out of college in 1983
and consider myself kind of a case study
in how many gay men were infected in in
82 and 83 and 84 because of the silence
of the epidemic in the in those early
years arriving in New York working on
Wall Street as a bond trader I was very
closeted I certainly wasn't hearing my
mayor or my President or even a
politically active gay community talk
much about hiv/aids I certainly didn't
hear that by 83 upwards of 50% of gay
men were already infected with this
virus they hadn't discovered the virus
yet obviously but that indifference
probably led to my infection and I found
out right after Rock Hudson died in late
85 when the country was in a panic the
tests had just come out earlier that
year and so I was one of the first to to
find out before I became sick and in
that sense I was lucky and one of the
reasons I'm probably here today but I
joined act-up soon after it was born in
early 1987 as I got more and more
frustrated about this silence that
happening around this epidemic well you
as I mentioned earlier you you're
featured prominently in the film how to
survive a plague I saw this film last
week and it's it's incredible I
encourage you all to to watch that but
let's look at a little clip from that
[Applause]

what's going on here and why there are
no treatments out there for people
living with this disease

building down that way dr. Anthony
pouches presiding the research
priorities for the National Institute of

down here because we think we should be

these are the people who know what's

day
[Applause]
that was you being taken down by by the
police at and at the NIH much younger me
yeah I think several of our panelists
we've seen younger versions I'm glad
there's no footage for me now why did
you feel those kind of protests were
were necessary well we were dealing with
first Reagan and then Bush two
administrations that that were came to
power largely based on what was called
the moral majority back then the
predecessor of today's tea party if you
were if you will and these were very
conservative administrations that have
been ignoring hiv/aids for years and and
as dr. Baltimore's a panel pointed out
was spending very little money at the
NIH on AIDS research
we had an FDA that was still probably
the most Iraqi see in DC as far as how
it slowly would it would approve
treatments and the deaths were just
racking up and so we our backs were
against the wall we could either roll
over and all die quietly or we could try
to guilt-trip the country into doing
something about what we were going
through and saving some lives so it was
it was about putting aids on the
national agenda it was about making the
country see what was happening and care
and then forcing the government just
actually starts spending major dollars
on AIDS research and in short order that
money appear and and you have you have a
couple graphs
that you brought one when dealing with
the issue of stigma and who was getting
AIDS Gallup has been asking a gay
related question to the American public
that's very antiquated now in today's
debate but it's the one that they've
been asking the longest and so they
continue to ask it so they can get this
wonderful thirty thirty five-year sweep
and it's basically about sodomy laws
that's why it's very antiquated but it
is do you think homosexual relations
between consenting adults should be
legal or illegal when they first started
asking that in the late 70s the numbers
were about even in the 40s but then as
aids became a story with with Rock
Hudson and a national panic broke out
there was a backlash that started
happening against attitudes against
homosexuals in this country you see that
red line which is the people thinking
that gay sex should be illegal
that started to to really sore and it
hit a peak in early 88 at 57% and then
in 18 months between that 88 number and
the next time they asked it in 89 it had
the biggest move in its history it
dropped 21 percentage points and the
only thing that happened historically in
the AIDS crisis at that moment was act
up bursting onto the scene and we had
the FDA demo that was that was followed
by the quilt AIDS became a huge national
story from that moment on for the next
few years with a series of large
demonstrations and they saw gay men and
lesbians fighting back it just
completely changed their attitudes for a
while against how they viewed us and we
successfully made them they may not have
loved us but they did not like the fact
that the government was ignoring us
while we were dying that hurt their
conscious but let's pull up that funding
slide and and take a look at the the
same timeline this is the NIH AIDS
research budget and how it started with
just a virtually nothing during the
Reagan administration by the time we got
to Bush we were getting up to two or
three hundred million and then during
act ups first five years and after
David's report we kicked out and rose
quickly to a billion and from there it
just climbs now it's over three three
billion a year and those dollars in this
age of austerity those dollars matter
those dollars are what eventually helped
us get the breakthroughs that we have
today and those dollars are ultimately
what we hope can find a cure and a
vaccine
I mean what else do you think
contributed to that rise in funding was
that all the work of act up and and the
advocacy community well no the
scientific community also acted up and
not not so loudly or obviously but used
whatever connections we had within
Washington to impress upon the
government the absolute necessity to do
something and we were all terrified
about how widely this virus would spread
we simply didn't know how widely it was
spread now in Africa in places in Africa
it has spread to 75% of the population
in the United States it hasn't spread
that widely but I find it still amazing
that for all of the information that
everybody has about this virus and about
protecting themselves against infection
we have 50,000 new infections every
single year so it is a problem to the
United States but it's a much bigger
problem on a world scale Susan in those
early years you were doing research what
impacted these protests have have a new
head how did that affect your life well
we were doing the work we went started
our research in 1981 with the first
patients that we saw the problem that we
were having was that we couldn't get
funding so we applied for our first
grant to studies Kaposi sarcoma in 1982
and the people who review these grants
in Washington didn't understand the
impact of what we were seeing so it was
not until 1986 or 1987 on that slide
where the graph is almost still
horizontal that we were able to get our
first grant so you know if if we had had
glasses that could have seen into the
future we could have had a much quicker
start on understanding this disease we
would have had five or six more years of
progress than we've had and
when did the relationship between
activists and scientists mature me was
it was it was it strong from the
beginning that there was an alliance or
there was a transition no we want one of
the things that was very painful for me
to see in the surviving a plague film is
that the activists didn't understand
that there was a very caring a very
active scientific community that was
trying to address the problem and there
there was very little interchange
between that community and our community
that began to change significantly I
would say in the late 1980s when the
activists really came to have a voice at
the NIH in terms of funding
and and priorities for research dollars
so we were probably close to ten years
into the epidemic by the time that the
two groups came together so so with that
research funding there there was some
success some limited success in the late
80s with with AZT then in 1996 a real
breakthrough with with the development
of highly active antiretroviral
treatment or heart Peter how did those
drugs change your life dramatic I
remember coming back from the Vancouver
aids conference where they you know kind
of put a stamp of approval that this was
real and all of us were we had been
through so many ups and downs and
disappointments that there was still
some suspicion like really yeah this is
gonna this is gonna change the map this
much but we all went on those that the
the treatments that had been on those
slides we all started Crixivan and and
to new nucleoside analogs and switched
to them I know I switched the month I
got back from Vancouver and most of my
friends did and within a month all of us
went undetectable which was just
extraordinary and we saw the death rate
in the US and most of the developed
world within two or three years dropped
by 80% so it was it was a game-changer
Bob how do these drugs work and are
there any limitations on that well the
drugs work in combination to block
different stages of the viral life cycle
they block many of them block the enzyme
that Dave Baltimore discovered reverse
transcriptase
they only work in combination and many
of the drugs that like AZT that have
been discovered 1987 which had only
prolonged life for nine months when used
in combination with another class of
drug called protease inhibitors blocking
another part of our life cycle
and another third drug could prolong
life indefinitely so it was it was
amazing to see how incremental
discoveries could eventually lead to the
home run which was prolonged life and
restoration of health and you've done
work to show that these can prevent
transmission not just treat people who
have AIDS
are they good enough to create an
aids-free generation well it that
depends not just on the drugs it depends
on how willing we are to use them and I
mean that by very broadly but yes these
drugs when used and and and sufficiently
to suppress viral the quantity of virus
in the body virtually eliminate
transmission from people who are treated
to their uninfected sexual partners and
more recently we've even discovered that
these drugs can prevent people from
acquiring the virus in the first place a
concept that we call pre exposure
prophylaxis so there's a pill for
preventing acquisition of HIV just
recently discovered and and approved by
the FDA highly effective and we're just
now starting to learn how best to use it
and who wants to use it we're gonna
we're gonna get into that with these
developments for many people HIV has
become a chronic disease in the way that
for some people diabetes is a chronic
disease but there been some some numbers
that are a little concerning the HIV
infection rate went up 22% among gay men
under 25 between 2008 and 2010 how big
an issue Peter is is complacency a sense
that this is no longer such a fatal
disease it is the issue
it depresses me to no end that I mean
while nine while the drugs that came out
in 96 were such a turning point and a
huge victory and saved so many lives it
was a double-edged sword in the sense
that it caused a lot of us to fall down
in fatigue after you know this 15 year
fight and and want to put this as far
behind us as possible and and and that's
sadly especially true for the gay
community in this country and and and in
many countries around the world where
they they want to move on they only want
to talk about gay marriage gay marriage
gay marriage and you'd be shocked to
realize how the gay leadership in this
country with our huge lobbying
organizations and our large foundations
how token their efforts are at this
point on hiv/aids and it's resulting
once again in a rising infection rate so
silence may not be equaling death like
it did in those early years but it is
equaling a whole lot of health care
issues the biggest health crisis facing
gay men today it remains so and we will
see the next generation at their current
infection rates of over two and a half
percent a year these are the
20-somethings right now if those
infection rates maintain fifty percent
of them will become infected by the time
they're 50 why should we continue to
have generation after generation of gay
men in this country in this country
become have a life of dealing with
health care issues and health insurance
issues and popping $25,000 worth of
pills every year we're gonna explore
those issues in our third part in much
more depth but I want to turn now to
talk about some of these breakthroughs
that that people here are
are working on and and see whether the
the strategies are in place whether the
tools are there to to truly end AIDS but
but we also want to hear from voices of
people whose lives have been touched by
the epidemic and so we asked AIDS
activists and some long-term survivors
to reflect on on how things have changed
and and what the science has meant to
them some of the people in this video
are HIV positive some are not but
they're all activists and and they've
all been working to try and and put an
end aids in the early days of AIDS if
you were diagnosed it was a death
sentence I'd see these amazingly
beautiful men reduced to just walking
skeletons 1993 was the worst year that
was the year I lost most of my friends
one hospital visit to one memorial
service to to the to a funeral to a
cremation service to a hospital visit
one after the other after the other
it's hard and if people don't come for
it and I understand why I didn't come
forward for 10 years I lived in absolute
fear and horror that I would be found
out those of us who remember the 1980s
still have the scar emotional scars of
the death and the dying and those scars
may have hardened and healed in some
respects but but they're still there one
day my roommate showed me this lump that
he had on his shoulder and you know this
is about 1981-82 and I went with him to
the doctor and the doctor said you have
AIDS
we didn't really know what to do what to
say and I said to him well can you give
us a referral and he said there are no
referrals you know are you religious
sometimes you would take him to a
hospital they discovered that you had
AIDS they didn't want to touch you I
mean there were times when when people
would die and be put in like black
garbage bags I mean these are the sons
of people that they were treated like
garbage people have a harder time
believing
that you even get HIV a from one active
unprotected sex in my case I think it
was one maybe two you know so with a
friend a good person someone I knew
someone I trusted someone who didn't
know that he had it it took me three
years to confirm that I was in fact HIV
positive because I didn't want to know
none of us wanted to know because if you
were HIV positive it probably meant you
were gonna have AIDS and then die
my boyfriend Michael Gault died of AIDS
Michael was on the protease lotery his
number wasn't called because it wasn't
approved in 93 his number didn't get
picked he died to me that such shows
what the meds did how if you weren't
lucky enough to have your number called
you died and if you were part of the
trial for the protease or lived long
enough to actually be somebody who could
just get it at a pharmacy you started to
live I remember that period where
friends who looked like they were gonna
die suddenly the retroviral drugs
started being available and they went
from being emaciated sick Kaposi's
everything to actually clawing their way
back into some kind of functional mode
so hallelujah that was amazing and
frankly had I not been in that early
clinical trial I might not even be there
today there are so many people who
didn't make it and I was right on that
cusp of you know had I been diagnosed a
little bit earlier I might not have made
it
people died back then so that others can
live today those who live today need to
know the sacrifice the those people who
died made in the 80s and the early 90s
so that their sacrifice wasn't in vain
we want to now turn to to some of the
exciting science that that's going on
looking for the next big big
breakthrough and we're gonna look at
three approaches of vaccines gene
therapy and and drugs I want to start
with with vaccines at a memorable press
conference in 1984 the Secretary of
Health and Human Services Margaret
heckler predicted that an effective AIDS
vaccine would be available within 2
years we're still waiting
David I want to ask you why has it been
so hard to create an effective vaccine
well first of all we always make fun of
that statement of Harvard health
hecklers but she had history on her side
when we discovered that a disease was a
viral disease
we usually knew how to make a vaccine
and vaccines came along pretty quickly
once once we figured out how to make
them and so we have vaccines today for
mumps and measles and smallpox and
chickenpox and polio and what both
whatever so some of us suspected that
this wasn't gonna be true for HIV and
the reason was because HIV is a chronic
disease that the immune system can't
control if the immune system could
control it then we wouldn't have the
problem we have and that one fact led us
to be suspicious that when you tried to
make a vaccine you were gonna discover
that the virus had already figured out
how to be resistant to the vaccine and
that turned out to be true and so this
virus and it's not uniquely true of this
virus but but there are very few lykan
has figured out a whole variety of
fascinating ways I mean from a
scientists point of view it's amazing to
see what's evolved to counter the immune
system to not be sensitive to antibodies
to not be sensitive enough to T cell
immunity so the T cell immunity can
used to protect against it and so we
have been unable to make a vaccine and
we have now seen fairly large-scale
clinical testing of a number of vaccine
candidates at phase three which is when
you really look for efficacy and they
have all largely failed one was partly
successful and we're still trying to
understand exactly why that was true you
know to see whether we can learn
something from that that'll lead us
forward well Susan your work is has been
around vaccines what's your strategy how
are you approaching this difficult virus
well I think it's very important for
people to understand that there are many
different strategies that can be used
for making a vaccine so it's not a
matter of a silver bullet we know how to
make an attack same to polio therefore
we can use the same methodology we can't
they're men five large-scale clinical
trials of vaccines four of them have not
shown efficacy one of them showed
marginal but statistically significant
efficacy I like what you said before
about the fact that the incremental
discoveries lead to the final home run
and incremental discoveries sometimes
are labeled as failures but an
experiment isn't a failure if you learn
something from it and so for instance we
had the failure with vaccine trial a
third large vaccine trial which was
called the step trial the step trial was
a real blow to the field because in that
trial individuals who got the vaccine
were more likely to get infected than
the controls I mean that is the worst
